body: @kareef928 would you be at all interested in this? If not, I'll do it, just lmk
@j1c @asaadeldin11 does anyone protest to this minor change?
nope, seems like a good change to me
Looks like a good change. Tho this really means scipy stats since the the other big stats package `statsmodels` does not follow this convention.

> Looks like a good change. Tho this really means scipy stats since the the other big stats package `statsmodels` does not follow this convention.

Fair point - yeah, I guess scipy is mainly the one I think we should care about. Though I'm curious where in statsmodels they don't do this, I clicked on a couple things that looked like tests https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/generated/statsmodels.tsa.stattools.coint.html#statsmodels.tsa.stattools.coint https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/generated/statsmodels.tsa.stattools.adfuller.html#statsmodels.tsa.stattools.adfuller and they at least looked like (stat, pvalue, ... otherstuff)

> > Looks like a good change. Tho this really means scipy stats since the the other big stats package `statsmodels` does not follow this convention.
> 
> Fair point - yeah, I guess scipy is mainly the one I think we should care about. Though I'm curious where in statsmodels they don't do this, I clicked on a couple things that looked like tests https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/generated/statsmodels.tsa.stattools.coint.html#statsmodels.tsa.stattools.coint https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/generated/statsmodels.tsa.stattools.adfuller.html#statsmodels.tsa.stattools.adfuller and they at least looked like (stat, pvalue, ... otherstuff)

Hmm yea I guess I was thinking based on anova (https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/generated/statsmodels.stats.anova.anova_lm.html#statsmodels.stats.anova.anova_lm) and manova (https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/generated/statsmodels.multivariate.manova.MANOVA.mv_test.html#statsmodels.multivariate.manova.MANOVA.mv_test). But it seems like others do follow that (stat, pvalue, ...).

Is the order of arguments important when the result value is a namedtuple? I think namedtuples are a great way to make order less relevant (in addition to other benefits like built-in documentation and (for `typing.NamedTuple`) type hinting.

issue.title: Modified order of return arguments in `inference` to match SciPy and other stats APIs
issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look at

- [ ] Does this PR add any new dependencies?
- [ ] Does this PR modify any existing APIs?
   - [ ] Is the change to the API backwards compatible?

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.

you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->
Fixes #856 

#### What does this implement/fix? Briefly explain your changes.
Changes the order of the namedtuple return of latent position/distribution test so that it is (stat, pvalue, misc_dict)

#### Any other comments?

body:
> Is the order of arguments important when the result value is a namedtuple? I think namedtuples are a great way to make order less relevant (in addition to other benefits like built-in documentation and (for `typing.NamedTuple`) type hinting.

The arguments were already namedtuples, so yes, doesn't matter much for people that access them via names. 

Still think we may as well respect a convention here
